habitat_description:
Throughout its range Megascops kennicottii primarily inhabits riparian hardwood environments of cottonwood, willow, oak, birch, aspen, sycamore, mesquite, and alder (Grinnell and Miller, 1944; Hardy et al., 1999; Hayward and Garton, 1988; Cannings and Angell, 2001; Wise-Gervais, 2005), but can also be found in: pine-oak woodlands (Marshall, 1957; Wise-Gervais, 2005), California oak woodlands (Cannings and Angell, 2001; Grinnell and Miller, 1944); pinyon-juniper woodland (Grinnell and Miller, 1944; Balda and Masters, 1980; Wise-Gervais, 2005); wooded desert washes (Hardy et al., 1999; Cannings and Angell, 2001; Wise-Gervais, 2005); broken conifer forest in coastal California (Grinnell and Miller, 1944); low elevation forests west of the Cascades, including bigleaf maple, alder, douglas-fir, western hemlock, and western redcedar (Cannings and Angell, 2001); parks and treed residential areas (Grinnell and Miller, 1944; Cannings and Angell, 2001; McCarty, 2007); desert uplands, with saguaro, ironwood, paloverde, and/or yucca (Grinnell and Miller, 1944; Wise-Gervais, 2005); and aspen groves with scattered douglas-fir (Fitton, 1993).

Western screech-owl avoids high elevation forests of mountain hemlock, subalpine fir, and/or englemann spruce (Cannings and Angell, 2001; McCarty, 2007). In the inland northwest, the species is not found in douglas-fir or lodgepole pine forests (Hayward and Garton, 1988). While some authors suspect use of ponderosa pine woodlands (Cannings and Angell, 2001; Cannings, 2004), the species has only been documented with ponderosa where it is either scattered among oak woodland or on the immediate edge of oak woodland (Marshall, 1957, Wise-Gervais, 2005).

Nests and roosts are located in tree cavities, saguaro cavities, and, occasionally, in dense thickets (Hardy et al., 1999; Cannings, 2004).

M. kennicottii has been documented at elevations from near sea level in the coastal states and Arizona (Bowles, 1917; Grinnell and Miller, 1944; Wise-Gervais, 2005), up to ~2400 m in both Arizona and Wyoming (Fitton, 1993; Wise-Gervais, 2005).

Radio-tracking by Hayward and Garton (1988) in the mountains of central Idaho, indicated that the species remains close to water, and their mapping of home ranges were confined to within 240 m of streams.
